text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revised IRM 4.7.6, Examination Returns Control System (ERCS), Reports.
The IRS replaced the Online 5081 (OL5081) system with the Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS). References to OL5081 have been replaced with BEARS.
Due to the move of the ERCS server from Solaris to Linux logins based on the user names are no longer used. The login is now the user’s Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) in lower case letters.
Due to the move to Linux access to ERCS is through Active Directory and passwords are no used. References to passwords have been removed.

N/A 4.7.6.15.1 (3) “Address Reports”: Add (3), information for maintaining the address table and the reports listed above can be found in the Login Menu chapter of the Technical Reference Manual. 4.7.6.15.5 4.7.6.15.5 “Database (DB) Error Report”: Removed Freeze Code and PICF Indicator from the table for working the DB Error Report as these are no longer included on the report.

) This IRM section contains information regarding ERCS reports. (

) Purpose: This section is intended to be used as a guide for users to locate reports in the ERCS menu system, determine if a report exists to meet the current needs of the user, and as a reference for how frequently particular reports should be run. (

) Audience: Employees in SB/SE, LB&I, and TE/GE, who have a need to generate ERCS reports for the following user types: • Admin: AIMS/ERCS (A/E) staff • Area: area, practice area and staff • CCP: Centralized Case Processing (CCP) users • DFO: directors of ﬁeld operations and staff • Group: all group users including shared administrative support staff Collections and TE/GE • PSP: Planning and Special Programs (PSP) users • Review: Technical Services (TS) and Joint Committee Review (JCR) users • Sample: National Quality Review System (NQRS) and LB&I Quality Review & Analysis (QRA) users • Territory: all territory managers over exam groups and staff • Limited: technical employees with access limited to input their time and generate speciﬁc reports (
) Policy Owner: The SB/SE Deputy Director, Examination, who is under the SB/SE Director, Examination. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE Director, Technology Solutions (
) Primary Stakeholders: LB&I (

) ERCS contains a variety of reports designed to meet the needs of the group function. This section discusses the following types of reports: • Employee Reports • Inventory Reports • Time Analysis Reports • Monitoring Reports • Count Reports • Statute Expiration Reports • Tax Auditor Reports • Territory Reports • Sample Review Reports • AIMS Error Reports • Check AIMS Results • Miscellaneous User Reports • Miscellaneous A/E Analysts Reports (

) Reports are only as reliable as the data that is input into the system. Every ERCS user plays a part to ensure the data on reports is up to date and accurate. If there is a question concerning how to answer an ERCS prompt when adding, updating, transferring, or closing ERCS records users should contact their manager or their local A/E staff for guidance.

Examination Returns Control System
) Reports are available to users based on the user’s setup (user type) and missions. Not all reports are available to all users. Exhibit
, ERCS Reports, shows which reports are available to users based on the user type. (

) Users must be aware of the potential for Unauthorized Access of Taxpayer Accounts (UNAX) violations from the use of ERCS. Data from ERCS should accessed only for IRS business purposes. Users should promptly retrieve ERCS reports from printers or fax machines in order to prevent unintentional disclosure. Audit trails are created and subject to review for all user of taxpayer data. For more information about UNAX, see IRM
, IRS authorized Access, Attempted Access or Inspection of Taxpayer Records (UNAX) Program Policy, Guidance and Requirements. (

) ERCS creates audit trails for selected changes to returns, employee records, and permission records. A special audit trail is also created when users enter Controls taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) or a taxpayer name on ERCS. See IRM
, Security, for more information. IRM
, Audit Trails, has a list of the changes in ERCS that produce an audit trail. (

) There are security checks within ERCS to ensure unauthorized users do not access programs and authorized users are kept within the boundaries of permissions. These checks are performed automatically and silently each a user attempts to access ERCS. The user has no ability to prevent the checks. For more information about permissions in ERCS, see IRM Permissions. (

) Audit trails are created when records are researched, added, updated, or deleted. Research should be limited to a user’s official business needs in to prevent unnecessary disclosure. Audit trails are also created for UNAX violations. These audit trails include when a user: • Inputs their own social security number (SSN). • Inputs the SSN of a spouse. • Attempts to view an IRS employee’s return without permission for return. • Attempts to update a return without permission for the return. • Inputs a name search that matches an employee’s name. ) Employee Reports by Employee Group Code is available to all users and a number of options that enable the user to ﬁnd a particular employee by by name, ERCS employee ID number, or to generate a list of all employees Code (either active, inactive, or both) in the AAC. (

) The report contains data extracted for the Summary Examination Time mission System (SETTS) transmission so it should be run prior to the end of the cycle to ensure the employee data is current. The report can be used to identify employee records that need to be inactivated or transferred. The also contains the employee’s work schedule as it appears in the employee work schedule proﬁle. Any issues with correcting data on this report should reported to the A/E staff. In particular the following values should be veriﬁed each cycle: • Name • Position code • Grade • Post of duty • Work schedule • ERCS status (active or inactive) Note: The SETTS program extracts employee and time information from ERCS the end of each reporting cycle. The data is validated and transferred to another server. This data is used to formulate the Examination Plan and is included on Table
, Examination Program Monitoring. Refer to IRM Outline of System, for more information. (
) The report must be run before and after re-organizations to ensure all employee records have been moved to their new groups (incoming or outgoing). (
) This report is also used by the A/E staff to verify employee records during sistance visits and operational reviews. (

) This report can be used to verify current, active employees at the territory or in the function and to ensure employees are in the correct group codes re-organizations.

The Agent Analysis is a historical document listing all of an employee’s SETTS time for a prior reporting cycle. It also contains other data including:

) An Agent Analysis is printed at the end of each cycle for each employee required to input time for SETTS. It can be re-generated up to one year the end of a cycle. Note: Below the line time (i.e. admin time, training, leave, etc.) is deleted from ERCS after
days. Time charged to returns may be retained longer depending on when the returns were closed and if they were part of a related group. If a user attempts to re-create an Agent Analysis for a over
days in the past, the information on the report will not be (
) This document is used by the employee to reconcile and verify that time applied during the cycle was correctly entered in ERCS. This should be as soon as possible after the cycle is complete. (
) The Agent Analysis document must be signed by both the employee and manager indicating the validity of the report. The signed document should retained in the group for three years. Refer to IRM

, Agent Analysis the special requirements regarding this document. Note: The Agent Analysis may be signed and/or maintained electronically as as it is kept on a secured Share Drive accessible by more than one user it can be retrieved up to the required three years. (
) The report can be used to alert management of issues such as: • Unusually large inventory of open cases. • Excessive time applied to a case. • Started cases with no current time applied. (

) The Alpha IVL includes all returns in a group or function. It can be used to compare ERCS data with the statistical sampling inventory validation data to reconcile AIMS and ERCS differences. There are some values that must be validated that are not included on this report such as the tracking code and the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) indicator. (

) The Cases Returned to Group report is available to review and CCP users. The report lists returns that have been returned to the group for additional to rection or action. This report can be used to ensure cases are returned to JCR, or CCP within appropriate time frames. Caution: Due to the length of time required to generate this report, it should be at the employee group code (EGC) level and not at the territory level. (
) When TS, JCR, or CCP sends a return back to the group on ERCS, a reason code (also known as re-established reason) is associated with the return. These codes are nationally deﬁned. Refer to Exhibit
, TS Reasons, and Exhibit
, CCP Reject Reasons, for a list of reject codes deﬁned for TS (including JCR) and CCP, respectively. (
) There are two reports named Closed Case Report on ERCS. The report discussed here is available to group, upper management, and PSP users. Refer to IRM
, Closed Case Report, on the Count Reports menu the report available to CCP users. (

) This report lists returns that were closed from a group within a speciﬁed frame. It can be used to monitor the number of returns surveyed and to compare the types of returns closed against the examination plan. (
) The In Transit Status Report lists returns in transit from the user’s group or function to another function. It includes returns in Status Codes
(TS and Report JCR),

The In Transit Status Report lists returns in transit from the user’s group or function to another function. It includes returns in Status Codes 21 (TS and JCR), 41 (PSP), 51 (CCP), and 81 (Appeals). It is used to monitor returns transit and to identify returns that need follow-up action by the sender.
Reminder: Some Areas are using electronic case ﬁles and no paper case ﬁle will be sent. An electronic case ﬁle indicator has been added to this report to identify these cases.

The PBC Transfer Listing, located on the Utilities Menu, Reorganization Programs, is used in conjunction with the Transfer Returns to Another PBC option when a reorganization makes it necessary to transfer returns in an AAC to another area. The report contains all the returns in the AAC entered and displays messages about returns that need to be updated prior to the move. When the option is run, the program displays a count of returns by the following categories: PSP, Group, Review (includes TS and JCR), PSP Suspense, and CCP. The user has the choice of including returns with over
for the report.
Returns with the following comments are ineligible for a PBC transfer:

Comment Meaning AAC DIFF The ERCS AAC does not match the AIMS AAC. AIMS UPDATE There is a pending update to AIMS. AMSOC An AMSOC has been generated for the return. APPROVAL PEND An update to the return is pending managerial approval. CLAIMED The return was claimed from PSP but the case has not been transferred to the group. INVALID GRP ST The return has a locally deﬁned status code that is invalid for the new PBC. NON AIMS PBC The destination PBC cannot be 217 or 218. NO TEFRA IND The return is a non-PBBA return, has an MFT 06 or 35, a status code greater than or equal to 12, and no TEFRA indicator. REQUEST The return has been requested on ERCS, but the request has not been sent to AIMS.
Comments that indicate possible issues but which do not prevent a PBC transfer are as follows:

Comment Meaning FRZ XX The return has a local freeze code represented by XX which will be removed when the AMSOC is processed on IDRS; indicates a freeze code may need to be added once the transfer on AIMS is complete. LOCAL GRP ST The return is in a locally deﬁned status code. LOCAL PROJECT #### The return has a local project code.

Comment Meaning LOCAL TRAK #### The return has a local tracking code. PENDING The return has been requested on ERCS, and the request has been sent to AIMS, but either the request rejected or the AIMS record has not processed against the ERCS record. SKELETAL The return is a skeletal record on AIMS and ERCS. STATUTE ## The statute is due to expire within 60 days; the number of days until expiration is shown.

Exhibit 4.7.6-8 (06-30-2022) Recommended Reports to use with SSIVL Validation

The following reports can be used to reconcile the differences between AIMS and ERCS. Many of these reports are used to identify the reason why returns are on the group’s inventory reports but not on the SSIVL or why the returns are on the SSIVL but not on the group’s inventory reports. Some of the reports can be used to explain why the codes on ERCS and the SSIVL do not match.

This report is used to identify closed returns on ERCS that are open on AIMS. Returns on this report will not be on the group’s ERCS reports but may be on the group’s SSIVL. (If the AIMS record is in a different AAC, the return will not be on the group’s SSIVL.)

This report is used in conjunction with the Overage Report (IVL) to validate each return in inventory against the group’s SSIVL. It is used to identify the record type of ERCS returns and to identify ERCS only records (penalty, collateral, etc.)

This report is used to identify the rejects that have not been resolved. (The returns or codes on ERCS will not match AIMS.) Rejected requisitions will be on the group’s ERCS reports but not on the group’s SSIVL. Rejected updates will result in the codes on ERCS not matching the codes on the SSIVL.
4.7 Examination Returns Control System

Report Notes Overage Requisitions Report This report is used to identify overage requisitions that are not on the group’s SSIVL. (Issues for these returns may include unapproved requisitions, rejected requisitions, or requisitions that dropped prior to being fully established on AIMS.) The report can also be used to identify skeletal records that have not fully established on AIMS. The creation date, which is not included on the report, should be used to determine how long the return has been on AIMS as a skeletal record. Related Returns Report (RRR) This report is used to verify the linkage on returns in related groups and to verify the correct codes are used on related cases. (The RRR is generated by the A/E staff from ERCS data. It lists all returns and identiﬁes potential errors on related returns. Most areas share this report periodically with their groups.) Work Awaiting Approval This report is used to identify updates that have been made on ERCS, but have not been approved. (The returns or codes on ERCS will not match AIMS.) These updates will be on the group’s ERCS reports but not on the group’s SSIVL.
